(NYSE:CI) Claudia Dawson, November 15, 2016 Analyst Insights Noteworthy Analyst Ratings of Two Stocks Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT), Big Lots, Inc. (NYSE:BIG) SHARE ON: Lewis Gonzalez — November 12, 2016 Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) went up 2.18% during trading on 11/11/2016, with the company’s shares hitting the price near $43.62. The stock had a trading capacity of 992.31TH shares. The firm has a SMA 50 (Simple Moving Average) of $38.02 and a SMA 200-(Simple Moving Average) of $36.01. This appreciation has taken its market valuation to 4.55B. Shares registered one year high at $43.20 and the one year low of $26.60. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) Analyst Evaluation Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) currently has mean rating of 1.80 while 5 analysts have commented the shares as ‘BUY’, 3 recommended as ‘OUTPERFORM’ and 1 commented as ‘HOLD’. The rating score is on a scale of 1-5 where 1 stands for strong buy and 5 stands for strong sell. The mean price target for the equity is at $43.19 while the highest price target suggested by the brokerage firms is $45.50 and low price target is $41.00. The mean price target is calculated keeping in view the consensus of 8 analysts. The mean revenue estimate for the ongoing quarter ending Dec 16 is $192.1M by 5 analysts. The average forecast of sales for the year ending Dec 16 is $725.26M by 5 financial experts. Earnings Summary In Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) latest quarter ended on 30 Sep 2016, company revealed earnings of $0.64 a share. The reported earnings missed the analyst’s consensus by $-0.01 with the surprise factor around -1.50%. In the matter of earnings surprises, it can have a huge impact on a company’s stock price. Several studies suggest that positive earnings surprises not only lead to an immediate hike in a stock’s price, but also to a gradual increase over time. Pay Close Attention To Analyst Ratings For Big Lots, Inc. (NYSE:BIG) Big Lots, Inc. (NYSE:BIG) shares currently have a mean rating of 2.50 while 3 analysts have recommended the shares as ‘BUY’, 3 commented as ‘OUTPERFORM’ and 8 commented as ‘HOLD’. The rating score is on a scale of 1-5 where 1 stands for strong buy and 5 stands for sell. The mean price target for the company’s stock is $54.27 while the highest price target suggested by the analysts is $60.00 and low price target is $40.00. The mean price target is calculated keeping in view the consensus of 11 brokerage firms. Big Lots, Inc. (NYSE:BIG) has a mean revenue estimate for the ongoing quarter ending Oct 16 of $1.12B, according to 11 analysts. The average forecast of sales for the year ending Jan 17 is $5.23B by 12 analysts. Big Lots, Inc. (NYSE:BIG) went up 4.38% during trading on 11/11/2016, closing at $50.26. The stock had a trading capacity of 990.95TH shares. The firm has a SMA 50 (Simple Moving Average) of $45.52 and a SMA 200-(Simple Moving Average) of $48.86. This appreciation has taken its current market value to2.26B and a price-to-earnings ratio to 15.79. Shares registered one year high at $56.06 and the one year low of $33.34. Earnings Overview For Big Lots, Inc. Company latest quarter ended on 31 Jul 2016. There were earnings of $0.52 per share. The reported earnings topped the analyst’s consensus by $0.06 with the surprise factor of 13.00%. Stocks Markets Analyst Research Technology About Us Advertising Contacts Privacy Policy Price Target Of Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) At $74.779 November 12, 2016 2:03 pm· Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) stock has a rating of 2.58 based on views of 19 brokerages. On this base scale, ‘1’ ranking is suggestion of investing in that particular stock. Price Forecast The sell-side specialists have $74.779 price target on pertaining equity. For the looming period, the possible range is $50 to $90. Prior to issuing of Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT)’s earnings, the predicted EPS was $1.36. For quarter ended on 2016-07-31, the EPS came $1.07, which saw deviation of 4.9% versus the analysts’ forecasts. Understanding consensus forecasts’ insufficiencies, shareholders can refer them to decide on equity direction during the earnings announcement. The analysts’ consensus is an aggregation of plentiful forecasts as given by market participants. It may not always be possible to pick up the best analysts’ opinion. The market has only few brokers who come up with unusually accurate predictions. Therefore, shareholders should adopt a wise and calculated approach to take an investment choice. In case of extreme variation in the calls as given by market experts, the target on stock is reached by opting for the mean target. In such events, securities can make for a good bargain following the most optimistic prediction, but not necessarily on the consensus. Investors can record a gain when the calls turn out to precise. Considering this fact of the limited usefulness of the released estimates, share value movement related to earnings performance, may be unwarranted. A plunge in the equity price that is a consequence of poor numbers released gives a buying opportunity. Similarly, better-than-expected statistics aren’t essentially good update; what’s more it can end in a decent chance to book profits. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) quarterly report can be posted close to 2016-11-17. While shareholders may sell right away in case of earnings miss, it’s possibly smart to assess carefully at why it failed to outshine the prediction. Savvy stockholders don’t depend merely on predictions; they take necessary steps to dig dipper into financial figures. 1 Chart Pattern Every Investor Should Know This little-known pattern preceded moves of 578% in ARWR, 562% in LCI, 513% in ICPT, 439% in EGRX, 408% in ADDUS and more... The Independent Republic Home Finance Industry Markets Opinion Home Opinion What Wall Street is saying about: Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) Opinion What Wall Street is saying about: Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) By Francis Lewis - November 12, 2016 Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) stock is currently trading at about $43.62 and lots of rating firms seem to have a target price set on the stock. The median 12-month price target of 8 analysts covering the company is $43.00, which suggests the stock could still gain more than -1 percent. The highest analyst price target is $45.50, which implies a gain of 96 percent. And roundups of analyst notes show that 5 are rating the stock a buy while 3 rate WAL a strong buy. There are 1 equity research firms suggesting a Hold and 0 consider it Sell. Wells Fargo issued their verdict on Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) recently. The rating firm gave a Market Perform rating to this stock in a research note on Sep 01, 2016.Keefe Bruyette analysts issued their verdict on Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) recently. The rating firm gave a Outperform rating to this stock in a research note on Mar 30, 2016. According to a research note published on Feb 11, 2016, analysts at DA Davidson have upped their rating on the company stock from Neutral to Buy. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) Insider Activity Several executives took part in recent insider activity for the stock. Its Director NAGY M NAFEES sold 27,700 company shares for $1053000.43, in a transaction on 2016-11-08. Following the transaction, the Director is left with a stake of 1053.43 shares, currently valued at $45951. Meanwhile, EVP Northern CA Administration Myers Daniel P sold 20,000 shares worth $760000, through a transaction dated 2016-11-08. Following the completion of the transaction, the insider is left with a stake of 91,913 shares, amounting $4009245.06. WAL Executive Vice President FROESCHLE DUANE RALPH also sold 10,000 shares, at a stock price of $38. This transaction occurred on 2016-11-07 totals $380000. After this transaction, the insider’s stake stands at 99,406 shares, with a market value of $4336090 Insiders own 3.51 percent of the stock. Robert G. Sarver is one of the largest insider shareholders in Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) , according to U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filings. The insider owns 1,155,075 shares which have current market value of around $50384371.5.Dr. James E. Nave,D.V.M. is another major inside shareholder in the company. The insider owns 257,876 shares as of 0.25%, currently worth $11248551.12. Paul Baker is ranked as third insider holder of the stock. This insider holds 246,755 shares with a market value around $10763453.1 as of recent close. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) Earnings Overview In Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT)’s most recent quarter, EPS moved to $0.64 from $0.60 in prior quarter and revenues reached at $191.83M versus $180.95M. Analysts had expected Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) to report earnings of about $0.65 per share on $188.62M in revenue. Looking forward, analysts on average predict that earnings for the current quarter would come in between $0.65 and $0.67. That is compared with the $0.57 in earnings per share it reported during the same period last year. Facebook Twitter Google+ Pinterest LinkedIn TAGS Inc. CLOSE Analyst Opinion Earnings Stock News About Contacts Stock Observer Stock News & Insights Analyst Opinion Earnings Stock News About Contacts Earnings Buzz For Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) By SN Staff Writer - November 12, 2016 28 0 SHARE Facebook Twitter Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) has average broker score of 2.58 as given by Zacks on 1-5 scale. A rating of 1 is recommendation of strong buy, and ‘3’ rating implies hold. Zacks assigned a rating of 2.58 a quarter earlier. There are ample stock views given from the street experts based on the financials in the market. Market has a price target of $74.779 on its stock. Analysts upbeat on the firm has shares price target of $90. The negative estimate is given as $50. Earnings Projections Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. (NYSE:WMT) can post financials around 2016-11-17 for the period concluding on 2016-10-31. EPS estimate is set at $1.36 depending on the poll outcome. Estimates of Zacks are not same as that of Thomson Reuters’ projections. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. posted EPS of $0.05 in last quarter, pointing to change of 4.9% over the street’s estimates. Alpha One measure securities ability to trade at least 1% during specific trading session and it names that daily impact score. The impact score is placed in the range of 1-100. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.’s impact score is set at 0.138. As on 2016-11-12, impact score was 77. Alpha One helps with increased due diligence of securities so that shareholders can get to know what they want to make the best investment choices. Outside the impact and daily sentiment scores, the entity also offers sentiment rating assessment. Investors can apply Alpha One’s sentiment rating to fix the potential degree a stock is possibly to be affected by bulletin and articles available about it on a certain day. Alpha One uses a balance in -1 to 1 range to quantity the potential outcome of news article on an equity. Investors can use the material to gauge how shares on their watch list are likely to be impacted by bulletin so that they can take appropriate choice. Updated: November 15, 2016 @ 11:02 am Full Forecast News Sports Life Entertainment Dining Buy & Sell Close Matt Rourke Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton walks off the stage after speaking in New York, Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2016. Clinton conceded the presidency to Donald Trump in a phone call early Wednesday morning, a stunning end to a campaign that appeared poised right up until election day to make her the first woman elected U.S. president.(AP Photo/Matt Rourke) Mayor Paul Soglin: Hillary Clinton never tried to win over the working class MAYOR PAUL SOGLIN | Madison mayor Nov 11, 2016 Matt Rourke Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton walks off the stage after speaking in New York, Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2016. Clinton conceded the presidency to Donald Trump in a phone call early Wednesday morning, a stunning end to a campaign that appeared poised right up until election day to make her the first woman elected U.S. president.(AP Photo/Matt Rourke) The definitive article explaining Donald Trump’s success was published two weeks ago in the Oct. 31, 2016, issue of The New Yorker. "The Unconnected: The Democrats lost the white working class. The Republicans exploited them. Can Hillary Clinton win them back?" The obvious and short answer is obvious: No. The longer answer is: She never tried. Election night I received a continuous stream of text messages from relatives and friends from coast to coast asking me “What’s happening?” “Why?” and the most poignant from our oldest daughter, 32-year-old Rachael, “Do Americans really hate women that much?” (No sweetie, just Hillary.) For 35 years, the Republican Party spun a narrative that the loss of jobs, good jobs, was the fault of Democratic regulation and taxes crippling the captains of industry. This tale of fantasy economics long discredited by a myriad of Democrats and some conservatives was never conveyed to working Americans, with the exception for a short duration by Bernie Sanders, and to a lesser degree by Elizabeth Warren, Nancy Pelosi and others who never had the national forum of Hillary Clinton. Clinton’s effort to embrace working Americans was short fused and undermined by her own attacks on Donald Trump’s insensitivities and the baggage she accumulated over 20 years. That said, the first successful, though not intentional, effort to sabotage the Hillary Clinton presidency was orchestrated by Bill Clinton when he embraced the George H.W. Bush NAFTA treaty and steamrolled his own party. For 35 years, the Republican Party spun its narrative, fooling the American workers and never being held accountable for its destruction of the American middle class as Democrats cavorted with Wall Street, bankers, and international financiers. For 25 years, the Democratic Party led by the Clintons sucked up to Walmart and Wall Street while claiming to defend the American workers. The Waltons might or might not have voted for Hillary, but rest assured Walmart workers and Walmart shoppers voted for Donald Trump. So did Kmart shoppers. Recall those standard questionnaires with a range of 10 spots from "extremely agree" at one end to "extremely disagree" at the other end and "neutral" in the middle. Now fashion it with "I care about my friends and neighbors" at one end and "I’ve been screwed over one too many times" at the other end. Screwed-over working America did not care that the Republican Party was mostly responsible for their plight, they did not care that the states with failed job growth strategies — like Wisconsin and Kansas — were run by Republican governors who screwed the poor and gave tax breaks to their buddies. Screwed-over Kansans and Wisconsinites, like the rest of America, saw each political party offer up a populist. The carefully orchestrated Democratic Party nominating system was rigged, polite, and stacked — and they rejected their populist, Bernie Sanders. The Republican Party's process was chaotic, impolite, and offensive — and they chose the clear, strong, angry voice: their populist, Donald Trump. The voters chose strident voice, not party. The consequences for the Democratic Party are a disaster. A majority of America did not care who created the mess — they wanted an alternative, they wanted revenge. As the campaign for president came to a close, there were tell-tale signs of the wheels coming off the Clinton campaign bus. There were too many undecideds, who in the end broke against the incumbent, against the establishment. And all those angry white males. Some of them were white men, others were brown and black men, and some were women. But there were too many angry genetic white males and the Clinton campaign ignored them. Then there was the failed media campaign. Two of the cardinal rules of politics were violated by Hillary Clinton, both lessons I learned 40 years ago in my first term in office. First, never attack the voters. No matter what you think of your opponents, do not call their base of supporters indecent, shameless, or deplorable. Secondly, never utter any opinion or position in private that you are not willing to say in public. If that was true in the 1970s it is more true today when everyone in the room has their own recording device. Having failed two rules, the Clinton campaign barreled forward to follow the third rule as the campaign concluded: Always play to your strength. The theme of the campaign was to continue to appeal to equity and social justice, the empathy of the American people. Donald Trump was a never-ending wealth of material for those who cared about their friends and neighbors. There was the attack on the disabled, the Mexicans and Latinos, and especially his crude direction to tell whoever was listening to “Go fuck themselves.” Rest assured none of Donald Trump’s friends ever wrote a book entitled anything like “It Takes a Village.” Those angry white males, those undecideds, that basket of deplorables wanted to read, “How to Get Yours and Screw Everyone in Authority.” Like this story? Get our best of the week sent to your inbox Sign Up! I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site consitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. If there is a surprise in all of this, it is that the Trump campaign did not double down and rerun the Hillary Clinton campaign's anti-Trump ads. In his New Yorker article, focusing on the divide between white working-class America and the rest of the nation, George Packer recounts: "When I asked her (Hillary Clinton) if this (educational elitism) had helped drive working-class Americans away from the Democratic Party, she hedged. 'I really don’t know the answer to that…'" How Clintonesque. She spent 20 years preparing to run for president. She took money from Wall Street while spinning them one story and her social justice colleagues another. She and Bill did amass a fortune and, when most politicians knew better, even set herself above the rest — not just the commoners but also the rest of the elites. There were the emails and then there were the foreign gifts to the Clinton Foundation while she was secretary of State. When she failed to answer Packer, once again she either lied or fudged. In either case, she was following in the tradition of every U.S. president over the past 35 years — fucking over working Americans. The difference is that whether it hubris, indifference, or arrogance, she did not have the filter to cover it up. Not when she answered Packer, not when she won the nomination, and not when she squared off against Donald Trump. It was obvious last spring that most Americans were mad as hell and there were two candidates who understood that. Bernie Sanders reflected and addressed it in a thoughtful, compassionate manner, not crying for blood, but demanding reasonable reforms. Donald Trump understood it and exploited and manipulated the long-suffering victims of both political parties. With Sanders out of the way, Hillary, who was too removed, too distant from the alienated, disenfranchised workers, sallied forth, offering platitudes and homilies but failing to give the people what they really wanted, the architects of the current economy. Trump never hesitated to sacrifice his bankers, his friends, and his investors. In meantime, none of us have a clue as to Trump’s real intentions on the economy. We know his stated positions on immigration and Supreme Court nominations but not much more. He may well create as much chaos for the Republican Party as he does for the Democrats, creating a very vulnerable GOP in 2018. The problem is Hillary Clinton smashed up the Democratic Party far worse than Lyndon Johnson and Hubert Humphrey could ever imagine. Paul Soglin is mayor of Madison. This column was first posted on his blog, "Waxing America."  Share your opinion on this topic by sending a letter to the editor to tctvoice@madison.com. Include your full name, hometown and phone number. Your name and town will be published. The phone number is for verification purposes only. Please keep your letter to 250 words or less. Sections Search the print archives Sections This copy is for your personal non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies of Toronto Star content for distribution to colleagues, clients or customers, or inquire about permissions/licensing, please go to: www.TorontoStarReprints.com News Insight The stabber, the victim, the lost son, and the wedding In 1999 Sean Clifton stabbed a stranger, Julie Bouvier. This summer they stood together, attending a wedding only made possible by the extraordinary aftermath of the crime and the filming of a documentary about it. Sean Clifton chats with Julie Bouvier at his son's wedding this August.  (Patrick Doyle / For the Toronto Star)   By Alex BallingallNews Sat., Nov. 12, 2016 Sixteen years after Sean Clifton tried to kill Julie Bouvier, he sat fidgeting on a hotel room couch, waiting for her knock on the door. The hands that drove a knife six times into Julie’s body now pawed at a plastic water bottle. His mind, once clouded with schizophrenic delusions, now buzzed for the words to tell her he’s sorry. The almost-killer hunched forward in his best suit and tie, his face pinched into the wounded look he wears so often, with something timid, something bashful, behind his eyes. A sound boom hovered above his head, but Clifton didn’t seem to notice. He also wasn’t preoccupied with the tripod-mounted camera that was trained on his face. I observed from the kitchen, out of the shot, as Clifton looked at the man who directed the scene from a green plastic chair: an Emmy Award-winning documentarian named John Kastner. “You’re the boss,” Kastner told him. “Say whatever it is, from your heart.” Clifton, 48, blinked and said “OK” in a cadence that evoked Eeyore, the glum donkey from Winnie the Pooh. Article Continued Below Kastner smiled at him. “Not to worry,” his voice chimed. “Que sera, sera.” ▶ Sean Clifton talks about his nerves before meeting the woman he stabbed. It would be the climactic scene of Kastner’s second movie about Clifton. The first, 2013’s NCR: Not Criminally Responsible, centred on his random attack of Julie at a Walmart in Cornwall, Ont., in October 1999. Clifton was found “not criminally responsible” for the stabbing, because of mental illness, and was held at an institution in Brockville until 2008, when he was released under supervision in the community. Julie and her parents also featured prominently in the first movie; it showed how they managed to understand and forgive Clifton, and even came to support him in his recovery. But while her parents met Clifton during the first doc, it wasn’t until now — for the sequel — that Julie was ready to see him. He had yearned to say sorry since the early months of his treatment, when guilt first pierced the fog in his mind. On this sunny August afternoon in downtown Ottawa, as Julie approached and steeled herself to hear her stabber’s apology in front of Kastner’s cameras, Clifton finally had his chance to repent. It was the climax of the story, yes, but as Kastner breathlessly explained while I observed the making of the documentary this summer, there was so much more to tell. Primarily, there was Jon McMahon, who sat a couch cushion away from Clifton and cracked his second Heineken of the afternoon. He was responsible for the sequel’s title: Not Criminally Responsible: Wedding Secrets. One secret was that McMahon is Clifton’s long-lost son, a shaggy-haired 31-year-old who decided to meet his biological dad after he saw the first doc. Another was that the decision to reconnect spawned an unlikely romance for McMahon: he was now engaged to someone with an intimate connection to both docs, and they would get married in three weeks beneath a gnarled tree in an Ottawa park, with the Bouvier family in attendance alongside Clifton — one big, happy NCR family. But first Clifton had to apologize. You could say the sum of his whole life was with him in the hotel room that day: the suffering and illness that led to violence; his years of treatment to get better; his confusion at the good that somehow grew from his horrible deed. All of it hung above this moment when he could say sorry, be forgiven, and maybe even forgive himself. I heard Kastner gently repeat to Clifton, “From the heart.” And Clifton, like Eeyore: “From the heart.” Three knocks on the hotel room door. Documentary maker John Kastner, left, chats with Clifton at the wedding. Kastner began filiming his first doc about the case years ago and just wrapped up the unexpected sequel.   (Patrick Doyle/FOR THE TORONTO STAR)   There’s a bridge in Cornwall that spans the tumbling mass of the St. Lawrence River. Clifton’s mother, Sheila, went there once when he was a little boy, and threatened to jump. He wasn’t with her but remembers the story because she told him she wanted to die. Fireworks crackled in the sky outside the Ottawa hotel as Clifton told me this story, the night before he was slated to apologize to Julie. He wore a green and blue striped T-shirt tucked into jeans that hugged his portly frame, with socks and Birkenstocks, and mirrored aviators that covered his eyes. His goatee and ponytail made him look a bit like the Comic Book Guy from The Simpsons, but with no whiff of smugness or condescension. It was easy to forget this was a man that tried to kill a stranger. Clifton was born in Cornwall in 1968, the youngest of four brothers by about a decade. He said his mother was institutionalized for mental illness before he was born, but he didn’t learn that she stayed at the health centre in Brockville until Kastner’s associate producer, Nicole Rogers, dug up the information in her research for the film. His parents were very strict when he was a kid. “There was no acting mad,” he said. “It was just: yes sir, no sir, three bags full sir. And that’s the way it went with them until the day they died.” (Clifton said his parents died a year apart in the mid-1990s.) When he was 12, Clifton was sent to a children’s psych clinic in Kingston to be treated for depression. He stayed there five days a week over nine months. After the treatment was finished, when he was 13, Clifton’s parents enlisted him in the Army Cadets. He stood out for the meticulous care of his boots and uniform, but when he was sent to a leadership training course at the Canadian Forces base in Trenton, he flubbed the test that called for teaching younger cadets how to salute. He said he was too nervous to try. Later, in high school, Clifton met Dawne Mullin, a local girl who turned out to be the only girlfriend he’s ever had. She’s also the mother of Jon McMahon, who was born in 1985, when Clifton was 17. He can’t remember if he held his son back then, but he has an image in his mind of baby Jon-to-be sleeping in a crib behind the nursery’s glass window. He and Mullin decided it was best to give him up for adoption. “Just like Moses,” Clifton said, “just had to send him adrift for a while.” The next few years were the “high point” of Clifton’s life. He backpacked Europe and North Africa, taught English in Hong Kong, and enrolled in some college courses back in Cornwall. His big dream was to one day land a white-collar job. “How wonderful it would be,” he said, “to be leaning on a counter with a cup of coffee in my hand, having a normal conversation with somebody.” But he was his mother’s son. In Hong Kong, he found himself flirting with suicide on the subway platform. He even went up on the bridge in Cornwall, but just like Sheila, he didn’t jump. In time, Clifton said he was “crippled” by his mind. He developed tics and patterns that he needed to fulfil, a symptom of intensifying obsessive compulsive disorder. He couldn’t bear cracks in the sidewalk, and took to tiptoeing around town with his head bent forward, straight down like an ambling Quasimodo. And before leaving a room with a clock, he’d have to watch the second hand spin for several minutes. He was also convinced of a war, where the forces of his hometown conspired against him, and he stood alone on his own side of an unbreachable chasm. He called it “Cornwall versus Hippie.” Julie Bouvier was a 22-year-old pharmacy worker, engaged to be married, at the time of the stabbing.   (GEOFF GEORGE photo)   Julie’s father Andy Bouvier owned a furniture store on Cornwall’s Montreal Rd. back then. There were windows at the front, and Andy sometimes recognized Clifton for his distinctive gait as he passed outside. “He’d do the thing with his toes,” Andy said, recalling the careful way Clifton shuffled around. “He was known to everyone in town for walking like that.” On Thursday, Oct. 7, 1999, at the apex of his afflictions with depression, schizophrenia and obsessive compulsive disorder, Clifton committed the seminal act of his life. He tried to kill Julie Bouvier. Around dinnertime, after a failed attempt to check into hospital, Clifton sauntered into the town’s Walmart and shoplifted a knife. Kastner’s first documentary detailed how Clifton fixated on the need to attack “the prettiest girl” he could find. Julie pulled into the parking lot. She was 22, a pharmacy worker who was engaged and excited to start a family. Clifton charged her as she approached the storefront doors. Wild-eyed and shouting, he repeatedly plunged the knife into her body. The blade missed Julie’s frantic heart by half an inch. Another strike passed close to her spine. Clifton cried out as Julie fell — “Die, bitch!” according to one account printed in the Guardian — and then stood trancelike above her as she bled at the Walmart’s threshold. He didn’t move until police came to arrest him. The Bouviers got the call around 7 p.m. Julie’s parents arrived at the hospital as she was being wheeled into surgery. They leaned over the gurney and her mom, Noella, whispered in her ear. “Everything will be fine.” She couldn’t tell if Julie was conscious. It took months, but Julie recovered. The following July, she got married as planned, and later had three children, just like she wanted. But Clifton still stalked her memory, a spectre that haunted her parents, too. Months after the attack, Julie went to the court hearing that eventually ruled Clifton was “NCR” for trying to kill her. “I didn’t know how close he’d be,” she remembered. “I said I’d never step foot in a courtroom again.” From then on, Andy took it upon himself to keep tabs on Clifton, who was sent 100 kilometres up the St. Lawrence River to the Brockville Mental Health Centre. Even on the night of the attack, when Julie was at the hospital, Andy asked her fiancé to drive him to the Walmart. There was police tape and blood on the ground. “If I had gotten my hands on him that night,” Andy said, “I probably would have killed him.” While he was institutionalized, Clifton had to attend annual hearings before the Ontario Review Board, a panel that follows each NCR patient’s progress and condition, and decides whether to soften the rules of confinement or proceed with eventual release. Andy attended each of Clifton’s hearings. He remembers once when Clifton stood up and claimed he was being treated unfairly. Andy was sitting directly behind him, and noticed that his own hand was clenched in a white-knuckle fist. “I didn’t understand mental illness at the time,” he said. “I was there for the protection of my family and to make sure he didn’t get out.” The Bouviers were Catholic, but about eight years ago, while still anguished by the stabbing, Noella and Andy tried a church for born-again Christians. They took a course there called “New Beginnings.” When it was finished they took it again, and then encouraged Julie to come to the new church, which she did a few times. The family also started researching schizophrenia and other mental illnesses to try to understand Clifton. In time, as Noella and Andy grew with their new faith and Julie focused on her young family, the Bouviers relinquished some of the ill will toward Clifton. “It showed us how to confront our emotions,” Noella said of her research and religion. “And believe me,” she added, “we had bitterness, resentment, anger, total un-forgiveness toward Sean.” Clifton was released from the institution around this time and allowed to live in Brockville under close supervision. Staff from the centre made sure he took his daily mélange of anti-psychotics, anti-depressants and pills for blood pressure and epilepsy. As he gained further control over his delusions, tics and paralyzing need to follow patterns, he moved into a home with other outpatients. Sean Clifton and his son, Jon McMahon, wait for the arrival of Julie Bouvier while filming a documentary in Ottawa in August. Clifton stabbed Bouvier in a random attack In 1999.  (Patrick Doyle/FOR THE TORONTO STAR)   Three years later, in 2011, Andy caught wind that there was a filmmaker that wanted to make a movie that featured his daughter’s stabber. By then he had accepted that Clifton’s release was inevitable, but he wasn’t entirely comfortable with it. He was lobbying his local MP for a bill to make it illegal for NCR patients not to take their medication. Andy went to see Kastner in Brockville. They spoke for a long time, and by the end of their conversation, Andy had agreed to appear in the movie himself. He went home and spoke with Noella, who jumped on board, too. And by the time filming had started, Julie decided to take part. Kastner called it a “classic two-hander” — Clifton struggling to recover, and the Bouviers grabbling with their anger. He decided to make an entire movie about it, and through the process of filming with Kastner, Julie and her parents agreed to extend their forgiveness to Clifton, though Julie was still unable to meet him. When the movie came out in 2013, it garnered a lot of attention from mental health advocates, lawyers and the media, with interviews touching on the delicate balance between the urge to see a perpetrator punished and the need for people with mental illness to receive proper treatment. “He’s a man who’s ahead of his time,” Andy said of Kastner. “People who wouldn’t probably seek help for mental illness — today they would. And it’s thanks to people like John Kastner.” In the years since, Andy and Noella have become advocates for people with mental illness, and were happy to hear that Clifton received an absolute discharge from the Ontario Review Board last year, meaning he is no longer under supervision and lives on his own in Brockville. Andy was even appointed to the board last March, and now participates in shepherding NCR patients back into society as functioning, independent people. Julie, meanwhile, broke her vow never to set foot in a courtroom again. With the trauma of her attack softened by her blooming empathy for Clifton, she goes there every day: she works as a court reporter in Cornwall. Sean Clifton with his son Jon McMahon and Jon's wife, Nicole Rogers.  (Patrick Doyle/FOR THE TORONTO STAR)   The Summer Olympics flickered without sound on the television behind the camera operator’s back. Jon McMahon stared at the screen, like a man concussed, sharing the couch with Sean Clifton: father and son, side by side, grasping for things to say to the cameras in the minutes before Clifton would meet Julie and apologize. McMahon turned to his dad and asked how he felt. “It’s not coming easy,” Clifton stammered. “I’m just going to say sorry … How do you make small talk with somebody you tried to kill?” McMahon grinned and raised his Heineken. “Here’s to a stab-free life?” Laughter subsided, and one of the film crew yelled out a 10-minute warning. The Bouviers were almost here. During a break, McMahon stood up, withdrew a pack of smokes and went out to the hotel room balcony. I followed him and shut the sliding door as he sparked a lighter and took his first drag. “Sometimes the conversation doesn’t flow,” he said. “I’m always worried about, how’s my tone? How’s this going to sound?” We both looked back into the room, where Kastner gesticulated and the film crew prepared to watch McMahon’s biological father, a man he didn’t meet until he was almost 30, apologize to a woman for stabbing her six times. McMahon’s lips curled into a smirk. “It’s a little weird,” he said. Growing up in Chesterville, a small town south of Ottawa, McMahon always knew he was adopted. So was his big sister. It was just a fact in his head. He found out about Clifton in his early 20s, after his biological mother messaged him on Facebook. He said he felt no inclination to meet Clifton, though he did connect with his mother, Dawne Mullin. He was fearful of how his adoptive parents would react. And there was the stark reality that this guy, his father, tried to kill somebody. His biology took on a new, sinister hue. “I was obviously concerned. Scared I guess, right?” McMahon said. “I became hyper-vigilant of my own thoughts… Is it just going to take this one thing and then I’m just going to snap?” Years passed, and then he heard about Kastner’s movie. One night, he watched it online with a buddy. His father’s face, before just a smudge in his mind’s eye, crystallized into Clifton’s face. And the thrust of Kastner’s film, the sympathetic portrayal of Clifton’s guilt and efforts to stay medicated, stirred in McMahon the desire to meet his biological dad. He had no idea what was coming. That night, after the movie, he emailed Kastner and told him he was Clifton’s son. He said maybe he could help Julie’s lingering unease with Clifton by coming forward, to underscore his humanity, that this guy was once in love and had a child. He also asked if Kastner thought Clifton could handle a reunion. Kastner showed the email to his associate producer, Nicole Rogers. The vivacious and keenly organized filmmaker from small-town Alberta had worked with Kastner on several movies in Toronto, and he trusted her deeply. “The letter was so moving,” recalled Rogers, now 29. “We couldn’t help but thinking, who is this guy? He’s so thoughtful.” Kastner invited McMahon to come meet the Bouviers at a screening of the movie at the Royal Ottawa Mental Health Hospital on May 16, 2013. Rogers didn’t plan to go until she learned McMahon would be there. The letter had piqued her curiosity. She booked a train ticket at her own expense, found a room at a local hostel, and went straight to the screening. “His was the only back to me when I came in,” Rogers said. Then he turned around. In a note she later shared with Kastner, Rogers described seeing his blue eyes, just like Clifton’s, and his “sun-kissed wavy hair.” “Our eyes met,” she wrote, “and in those milliseconds I experienced the closest thing I can think of to describing love at first sight… This man I had just met, Jon McMahon, had come into my life like a ray of sunshine and I didn’t want to let go.” This wasn’t lost on McMahon. He felt the same grip when he met Rogers: he was immediately attracted to the young woman with blond hair who exudes warmth with an easy laugh and a ready smile. When McMahon told me the story of how he met Clifton for the first time, weeks later at a food court in Ottawa, it was like a footnote to his feelings for Rogers. He asked Clifton if she had a boyfriend. “I was enthralled,” McMahon said. “It was unlike any other experience I’ve had.” They started emailing and agreed to meet again. Then again. And again. Over time, she was able to help him understand his father, his illnesses and his dread and self-disgust with the knowledge of what he did. Rogers dropped her new life in Toronto’s documentary film world to move to Ottawa and be with McMahon, a part-time personal support worker who also goes to goes to university. Last spring, after they were engaged, McMahon and Rogers went for a bike ride. They pedalled into a lush park, and came upon a wooden bridge that crested a glassy stream dotted with lily pads and algae. On the other side of the bridge, a gnarled tree with a trunk like a golf cart stood on the muddy shore. Its thick limbs twisted in a leafy canopy above a clearing. This was where they would marry. But first there was a movie to shoot. This past August, in that hotel room in downtown Ottawa, Rogers stood in the kitchen, producer and film subject, with a microphone on her blouse and instructions from Kastner to bring snacks and champagne after Clifton apologized to Julie. A text message arrived. The Bouviers were downstairs. Kastner bounded across the room and said to McMahon, “They’re going to knock and you’re going to answer it. And don’t look at the camera! You’re going to answer it and que sera, sera!” Rogers whispered in the kitchen. “My heart’s pounding,” she said. “This is why I’m glad we’re doing this before the wedding!” Sean Clifton makes a toast with his son Jon McMahon, left, Jon's fiancee and documentary associate producer Nicole Rogers, second from left, Julie Bouvier, second from right, Julie's mother, Noella Bouvier, and Julie's father, Andy Bouvier, in Ottawa this summer.   (Patrick Doyle/FOR THE TORONTO STAR)   Three knocks on the hotel room door. Apprehension walloped around the suite as McMahon stood and strode to the hallway, a camera guy stutter-stepping in his wake. He pulled open the door and someone, I think Andy Bouvier, said: “Good to see you.” “Good to see you,” McMahon replied. I strained to listen, pen poised. Here they come … CUT! Kastner stopped the action and McMahon returned to the couch. John Westheuser, one of the principal camera operators, called through the door. “Count to 10, then knock!” A few seconds passed in silence. Three knocks on the hotel room door. Again. McMahon answered it and the greeting was repeated — “Good to see you.” “Good to see you, too.” The Bouviers entered, and Julie drifted toward the couch in a white blouse with an air of serenity. When I heard her speak, I wrote in my notebook: “sweetest, gentlest voice.” He didn’t hesitate. Clifton: Julie, there’s something I wanted to say for 16 years now, and that’s that I’m sorry for what I did to you that day in the Walmart parking lot. Julie: Tha-thank you very much for your apology. Clifton: I know I can’t make it all go away or make it like it never happened or anything like that. But I’m sorry. Julie: Sean, I know that I was there at the wrong place, the wrong time and you were very ill and I completely understand. And I’ve never held that against you. Clifton: Thank you. Julie: I’m very, very happy.” It took 66 seconds. Once the apology was out of the way, the intensity of the moment gave way to the warmth of a neighbourly, almost familial visit. McMahon chatted with Noella and Julie, Clifton and Andy talked about fishing bass near Cornwall, and Rogers waltzed in with tall glasses of champagne. Cameras rolled and Kastner smiled at the scene, soaking the moment. “Well,” Clifton said, “I’d like to make a toast. Here’s to Julie. May you live long and prosper.” Glasses clinked and Clifton, for the first time in his 48 years, took a sip of champagne. He told me later it was like an explosion in his mouth. It just went poof. Jon McMahon marries Nicole Rogers on Aug. 25, under a gnarled tree in Ottawa. Rogers was moved by the young man who emailed documentary maker John Kastner after watching his movie about his father.   (Patrick Doyle/FOR THE TORONTO STAR)   Elegant string music wafted from a speaker plugged into an iPad, as mosquitoes flitted in the August heat, landing on congregants in the clearing under the gnarly tree. Nicole Rogers floated across the wooden bridge and entered the clearing, radiant in a white dress with French braids in her hair. The crowd parted and she walked straight to McMahon, who stood under the canopy of branches and leaves, copiously perspiring in a grey, three-piece suit. Julie Bouvier stepped forward and snapped a photo on her phone. Andy and Noella were there, too, along with Kastner and his crew, documenting the denouement of their sequel. Before the ceremony, I drove to the park with Sean Clifton and a couple of the crew members. He said he could never imagine a day like this. “I never dared look this far in the future,” he said. “It wasn’t even a dream.” He stood at the back of the crowd in the clearing, somewhat stiff in his suit and aviators. Up at the altar, McMahon sweated and Rogers held his hands and they promised to love each other and share the journey of life together. ▶ Sean Clifton talks about his relationship with son Jon and his emotions looking back on how his life has changed. Later, there was a reception at a fashionable restaurant on Elgin St., where Kastner’s cameras crowded around a table near the window that had places for Clifton and the Bouviers. The newlyweds came over to chat with Andy and Noella, and Clifton stood up to hug his son. It was hard to hear what Clifton told him, but the microphone picked it up. “I love you.” Speeches were delivered, toasts were made and waves of laughter and happy conversation swelled through the room. In the midst of the action, Clifton poked at his food and stared at the tablecloth, his face blank — like he was alone in the togetherness. After dessert, Kastner brought him into a side room, where he sat in a chair beneath a stage light for a wedding night interview. When they were about to wrap up, Clifton woodenly declared he wanted to discuss “how all the people in that dining room are there because I violently attacked somebody.” Kastner, leaning forward, asked him to elaborate. “John, honestly — I don’t see much positive that came out of this disaster. I almost murdered somebody, and maybe we’d be better off if I hadn’t done it,” he said. “I’m sure we would be better off.” “But the fact is,” Kastner offered, “there would be no marriage tonight …” Clifton bristled. “Well,” he said, “I can’t really excuse myself because my son found a nice wife and some things have gone right.” The director was taken aback. After a few seconds, he said “cut” and Clifton left without fanfare in a cab to his hotel. Kastner said he’d never heard him talk with such pessimism about the wedding. He’d been proud and upbeat in other interviews. Everyone clearly wanted a happy ending, Kastner maybe most of all. But the only one to expressly deny it that night was Sean Clifton. He looked around the room, at his son and Rogers and the Bouviers, and he saw a tragedy narrowly averted. In his moment of redemption, was there really any closure at all? Earlier that day, I asked him about this; whether good that unfurls from the consequences of a horrible act can make it less bad. “I don’t know,” Clifton replied. “I’ll probably think about that for a long time.” Then his eyes softened and took on that wounded look. “I don’t think it does,” he said. Broadcast times: The original NCR: Not Criminally Responsible Thursday, Nov. 17 at 9 p.m. on CBC-TV Firsthand After the airing, the movie can be streamed at cbc.ca: The sequel Not Criminally Responsible: Wedding Secrets Thursday, Nov. 24 at 9 p.m. on CBC-TV Firsthand After the airing, the movie can be streamed at cbc.ca: www.cbc.ca/firsthand/episodes/not-criminally-responsible-wedding-secrets The Morning Headlines NewsletterDelivered daily to your inbox. Technology Apple Science Cars Celebrity Movies Business Black Friday Holiday Gifts     How To Find NES Classic, Hatchimals, Pokemon Go Plus And New Nintendo 3DS On Black Friday Posted: Nov 12 2016, 3:45am CST | by Luigi Lugmayr, Updated: Nov 12 2016, 11:20am CST, in News | Black Friday   This story may contain affiliate links.   The most challenging Holiday gifts to buy this year have crystalized. Here is how to succeed buying them. Update: NES Classic now on sale by resellers on Amazon starting at $189. How To: Find Nintendo NES Classic In Stock We have not seen anything like this in years. This Holiday season shoppers are faced with more gifts than ever that are hard to find due to high demand und extreme low supply. At the center of the shortage fiasco is Nintendo. The Japanese video game maker is not able to satisfy demand for the Pokemon Go Plus since months and has angered many fans yesterday with the bodged launch of the Nintendo NES Classic Edition console. Add to the misery the upcoming $99 New Nintendo 3DS Black Friday edition, which will likely cause fist fights in the Walmart Black Friday sale. Nintendo is joined by toy maker Spin Master. The company landed a surprise hit with the Hatchimals Eggs. Who knew that we are ready for a Furby again. It is still early and there are ways to buy the aforementioned hard to find holiday gifts at regular or sales prices. I have personally engaged in hunting down the released items in online shops like Hatchimals and NES, and it is very difficult. As soon as a NES or Hatchimals shows up in stock at a retailer, they are gone in seconds. Find below the best practices and links to have a fighting chance on buying a Nintendo NES mini, Hatchimals Egg, Pokemon Go Plus or New Nintendo 3DS. How to Buy Hatchimals Walmart is the only store that has advertised a Hatchimals Black Friday deal. Walmart will offer the $48.88 Hatchimals deal it is also already offering now in the Walmart Black Friday 2016 sale beginning on Thanksgiving Day. As reported, I managed to buy a Hatchimals in the Walmart online store for $48.88 last week. Read how I have succeeded in scoring the $48.88 Hatchimals deal. To get the $48.88 Hatchimals deal on Black Friday is likely going to be messy, depending how many Hatchimals Eggs Walmart is hoarding for the Walmart Black Friday sale in stores. Even if Walmart stores would have a whole transport container full of Hatchimals, they crowd would clean it out within a minute. Our recommendation is to try to find a Hatchimals in stock online before Thanksgiving. Prospectors have driven the prices of Hatchimals up to around $150 on the Amazon Marketplace. The MSRP of Hatchimals is $59.99. Read on to Find out more ways to find Hachimals. How to Buy Nintendo NES Classic The $59.99 Nintendo NES Classic Edition console launched on November 11 in stores and online. The supply was extremely constraint in stores and especially online. Right now all stores are sold out of the retro 80s TV gaming console. Even NES accessories are hard to come by. The in-stock notification on the Nintendo NES Classic Edition page on amazon.com is too slow for ultra-high demand items like the NES Classic. You need to use real-time stock tracker tools. Read our NES Classic buyer's guide to find out how. Resellers have started on the Amazon marketplace to offer the NES Classic starting at $189 plus $12 shipping. Other deals for the NES Classic on the Amazon marketplace are $250 and up.  The deals on Amazon's marketplace are more reasonable than on eBay. On eBay prices of the NES Classic are going crazy, some listing ask $13,000 for the $59.99 NES. I assume these sellers hope that Kanye West just absolutely wants a NES Classic now. The lowest offers are around $300 on ebay.com. These outragous prices might be the reason Amazon does not allow NES resellers yet on its marketplace. How to Buy Pokemon Go Plus The Pokemon Go Plus is the most frustrating to find as there is just no new inventory coming in. The $34.99 Pokemon Go accessory has been spotted in stock at amazon.com for 1 minute once last week. All other online stores that carry the Pokemon Go Plus had no stock. Nintendo initially promised new stock for end of October. That did not materialize. Resellers offer the Pokemon Go Plus for $100 on Amazon's Market Place. How to Buy $99 New Nintendo 3DS Nintendo announced a new special edition of the New Nintendo 3DS console for Black Friday 2016 for $99.99. The hand-held console does not come with a game at this lowest price in history of the 3DS. The $99 3DS will go on sale on Thanksgiving Day at Amazon, Walmart, Target, Best Buy, GameStop and more. The $99 New Nintendo 3DS will sell out as one of the first Black Friday items on Thanksgiving Day. The 3DS is a perfect Holiday gift for kids and at $99 a bargain. So far only Walmart is listing the $99 Nintendo 3DS online. Check if Amazon.com has started to list the new 3DS deal. The first big Black Friday 2016 Sale is underway on Saturday at Sam's Club. The big three Black Friday 2016 ads are released. Walmart, Target and Best Buy published their highly anticipated Black Friday 2016 ads on November 10. Find over 50 released Black Friday 2016 ads in our Black Friday ads list. We have compiled everything you need to know about Black Friday 2016 in our Black Friday 2016 guide. Browse the big three Black Friday 2016 ads below: Walmart Black Friday 2016 Ad Target Black Friday 2016 ad Best Buy Black Friday 2016 ad Read also everything we know about the Amazon Black Friday 2016 sale, which we predict will be largest Black Friday sale in history. Black Friday 2016 is on November 25. Read the latest Black Friday 2016 news.  Walmart is kicking off Black Friday immediately — but there's a catch Hayley Peterson Nov. 10, 2016, 12:01 AM 65,143 facebook linkedin twitter email print Walmart is kicking off its Black Friday deals this week. AP Walmart just kicked off some of its Black Friday deals more than two weeks before the shopping holiday. But there's a small catch: the deals are available only to users of Walmart's app for now. The discounts available through the app include a Hitachi 65-inch 4K Ultra HDTV for $599 ($400 savings), an Xbox One S 500 GB Minecraft console with a bonus controller for $279 ($20 savings), and an Acer 15.6-inch Core i5 laptop for $299 ($150 savings). The rest of Walmart's Black Friday deals will become available to all customers online at 12:01 a.m. Eastern Time on Thanksgiving Day, the company said. The in-store event featuring "doorbuster" deals like $230 off a $628 Samsung 50-inch Smart 4KTV will kick off at 6 p.m. that day, which is in line with what the company did last year. Some industry experts have said the significance of Black Friday is diminishing as an increasing number of retailers start offering holiday discounts days and weeks before the shopping day. But Walmart's chief merchandising officer, Steve Bratspies, said Black Friday remained the biggest shopping event of the year. "We think it's still the biggest event in retail that customers get really excited about," he said Wednesday in a call with reporters. An employee adjusting a large ribbon on a television display at Walmart in preparation for Black Friday in Los Angeles in 2014. REUTERS/Jonathan Alcorn In preparation for this year's demand, the retailer has increased its Black Friday merchandise by 50% on Walmart.com over last year. "I said it before and I will say it again: We will win the season on price — on Black Friday, on Cyber Monday, and every day before and after," Bratspies said. "That means delivering the Black Friday deals we're known for in stores, online, and on our app. And, we've secured significant availability of these items. We pride ourselves on not being the retailer who advertises a great price and then only has a few available." Here's Walmart's top Black Friday deals that will be available in stores and online on Thanksgiving, according to the company: 11 Televisions including 4K Ultra HDTVs, such as a Phillips 55-inch Smart 4KTV for $298 (special buy) and a Samsung 50-inch Smart 4KTV for $398 ($230 savings). Other television offers consist of a Vizio 60-inch HDTV for $398 (special buy), a 40-inch HDTV for $125 (special buy), and a 50-inch HDTV for $225 (special buy). Toys including the toy of the season, Hatchimals, for $48.88, Disney Princess Cinderella Royal Dreams Dollhouse with Furniture for $88 ($61 savings), Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles RC Mikey for $39 (a Walmart exclusive at a $10 savings), and Razor Hovertrax 2.0 Hoverboard for $273 ($125 savings). Drones including the DJI Drone Phantom Standard 3 for $369 ($130 savings), the Promark 3D Virtual Reality HD Drone for $99 (a Walmart exclusive at a $49 savings), and the Sharper Image Video Drone for $30 (special buy). Connected Home items such as the Nest 3rd-Generation Learning Thermostat for $199 ($50 savings) and the Nest Cam for $149 ($50 savings). Video Game Consoles and Games like the PlayStation 4 Slim Uncharted 4 500GB bundle for $249 ($50 savings) plus a $30 gift card and the Xbox One S White 500 GB Battlefield bundle for $249 ($50 savings). Walmart will also offer nearly 90 video games starting at $8. A$99 iPhone 5s 16GB on Straight Talk Wireless ($50 savings). 10 Laptops and Tablets including the Samsung Chromebook 3 for $119 (special buy), the HP 15.6-inch Touch Laptop for $249 (special buy), and the iPad Mini 2 32GB for $199 ($70 savings). More than 750 DVDs and Blu-ray Movies starting at $1.96. Fitness Wearables including the Fitbit Charge 2 for $129 ($20 savings), the Fitbit Alta for $99 ($30 savings), and the Fitbit Flex 2 for $69 ($30 savings). Pajamas and Slippers such as $4.75 Licensed Kids Pajamas and $7 Ladies' Novelty Character or Emoji Slippers (special buy). Home and Outdoor Favorites including $9.76 kitchen appliances (special buy), Hotel Style 1,100 Thread Count Sheet Set for $25 (special buy), Hotel Style Down Alternative Comforter for $20 (special buy), and Pioneer Woman 27-piece Porcelain Enamel Nonstick Cookware Set for $89 (special buy). Walmart will also offer a Blackstone 2-Burner Propane Griddle or Expert Grill 4-Burner Propane Grill, available for $99 each (special buy). A 14-foot Trampoline Combo (includes mini ball and hoop) for $159 (special buy). TechnoBuffalo Site Navigation Content All News Reviews Videos Galleries Products Giveaways Sections Menu Left Mobile Tablets Gaming Apps Accessories Computers Gadgets Internet Menu Right Business Cameras Cars Design Home & TV Lifestyle Software Science Series Ask The Buffalo Buffalo Gear Guess the Phone Rettinger’s Riffs Rumor Roundup The TechnoBuffalo Show TechnoBuffalo Plays More The Crew About Us News Tips In the News Work at TechnoBuffalo Advertise With Us Facebook Google+ Instagram Pinterest RSS Tumblr Twitter YouTube Scrolling Enable Endless Scrolling Disable Endless Scrolling Share Tweet +1 Submit Front Page /Gadgets/Deals/Gallery Gadgets Walmart Black Friday sale has crazy-good tech deals By Todd Haselton | November 11, 2016 Share Stay Connected with Us! Follow TechnoBuffalo Walmart recently revealed all of the items that will be available in stores come Black Friday. The weekly ad is chock full of tech, including plenty of discounted HDTVs, smartphones, accessories, streaming gadgets, home cameras and more. I took screenshots of the ad, which you can peruse at your will, but there are some standout deals that I spotted. If you buy a Galaxy S7 or iPhone 7 on AT&T or Verizon, for example, you’re eligible for a $250 Walmart gift card. You need to set an appointment ahead of time, however. Walmart’s Black Friday deals will save you big on tech For folks interested in creating a smart home, the Nest will be discounted from $249 to $199. The Nest Cam will cost $149, down from $299. For gamers, the Xbox One S Battlefield 1 bundle is priced at $249, down from $299. There are more than 65 games priced under $25, too, with many as low as $15 or $8. If you’re in need of a new laptop, Walmart has a variety of Windows 10 machines that are discounted down to as low as $99. Those super-cheap machines don’t always perform well, though, so keep that in mind before buying one. If you love movies, head to Walmart for those, too. More than 260 movies will cost just $3.96. Sure, most of us don’t use DVDs anymore, but if you buy a Disney movie, you can easily grab a digital copy for your smartphone or tablet. Boom, huge savings. And finally, TVs. There are tons of options, including a 4K 60-inch Samsung Smart TV priced at $648, which seems like a pretty good deal to me. Prices range from $98 for a 24-inch display to $798 for a 65-inch Samsung Smart TV, a $200 discount on the latter. Check out the full list in the gallery above, or hit the source to browse the full collection that also includes non-tech items. The sale kicks off at 6pm local time on November 24 in-stores. Good luck. Source Walmart Topics #Black Friday 2016 #Walmart Todd Haselton Todd Haselton has been writing professionally since 2006 during his undergraduate days at Lehigh University. He started out as an intern with MaximumPC Magazine and has since written for Ars… Read More Our Crew | About Us | Contact Us © 2016 TechnoBuffalo LLC. All Rights Reserved. facebook twitter pinterest facebook twitter pinterest All News  Mobile Phones Events Apple iPhone  BlackBerry Concept Phones Google Nexus  HTC  LG Microsoft Motorola  Nokia  Samsung  Sony  Phone Comparison  Accessories Mobile games Apps Android OS Apps iOS Apps BlackBerry Apps Windows Phone Apps Other Apps Software  Android OS  BlackBerry OS  iOS Windows OS  Other Software Tablet Video Hands-On Reviews  Phone Comparison Others Skip to content Homepage Events Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad includes Mobiles and $300 50-inch 4K TVs Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad includes Mobiles and $300 50-inch 4K TVs Categories EventsAuthor by Adam November 11, 2016 1,058 0 We are still two weeks away from Black Friday 2016, but the deals just keep on coming. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad has just leaked, and we are back to tell you what you’ll want to watch for when it comes to mobiles. The Best Buy Black Friday ad was beastly, and the folks at Wallyworld are coming in at a close second at 30+ pages. The Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad is full of tech, toys and other wares which means there is a little something for everyone. We’re going to start with the mobile phone deals, of which there are plenty. That said, we would be remiss if we didn’t mention those 4K 50-inch TVs for $300 bucks. Good luck… Black Friday Apple deals usually aren’t all that great, let’s just be honest. This year things have improved a bit as the Walmart Black Friday 2016 ad has the iPhone 5s for $99 through Straight Talk while the 32GB iPad mini 2 rears its head again at $199. There are some Apple accessories and a $250 gift card offer through AT&T and Verizon on the new iPhone, but that’s about it. With Android, the choices are vast as usual. You can get the same gift card deal on a wide variety of Samsung branded handsets or opt for Straight Talk. They have the Galaxy Luna, Galaxy S6, and the Samsung Galaxy Sky up for grabs. AT&T has the Huawei Ascend XT on a prepaid plan for $49 and Big Red has the $49 Galaxy J3. Nothing crazy, but there are more deal hiding in the Black Friday ad. There are several deals with slates as well during the Walmart Black Friday sale. You can grab a 7-inch RCA tablet for $29 or the Samsung Tab E 7 lite for $49. Just don’t expect the world from those slates. The Lenovo Tab 3 10.1 is quite a bit better though, and is listed for only $99. Accessories include the Fitbit Flex 2 for $69, the Alta for $99 and the Fitbit Charge 2 for $129. The usual offers on media streamers, headphones and various other mobile goodies are present as well. Black Friday 2016 may not kick off for several more weeks, but that will not stop the onslaught of deals from coming. The Walmart ad is one of around a dozen we’ve seen this week, and we expect more to drop over the weekend. Rest assured, we will keep you in the loop on all the mobile Black Friday deals as we come across them. MENU Tech Science Health Culture Reviews Features Videos HOMEPAGE Tech Gadgets Computers Phones/Tablets/Mobile Tech Wearable Tech Apps/Software Business Tech Internet Car Tech Security Apple Google Microsoft Smart Home Science Space Earth/Environment Animals Material Science Ancient Health Healthy Living/Wellness Medicine Public Health Neuroscience Culture Movies/TV Shows Video Games Comic Books Life & Style Viral Celebrities Reviews Wearable Tech Features Tech Advertisement facebook twitter reddit Comment google+ linkedin Email What's app digg Walmart Black Friday 2016 Deals For Video Games: Xbox One S Bundle, PS4 Slim Bundle And Lots Of Games! 11 November 2016, 6:21 pm EST By Aaron Mamiit Tech Times PlayStation 4 (PS4) - Five Surprising FactsNow Playing Xbox - Five Surprising FactsNow Playing Walmart will again be a major participant for Black Friday. The retail company has already released its Black Friday 2016 deals, but we now take a closer look at what is being offered when it comes to video games.  ( Microsoft Xbox ) Advertisement Black Friday 2016 is just around the corner, and for gamers, deals on consoles, accessories and games will be everywhere. Walmart is one of the major participants in the annual shopping frenzy, a trend that will not be ending this year. The massive retail company has already released its Black Friday 2016 deals, revealing that gamers have a lot of things to look forward to in their local Walmart stores for the holiday shopping. Here is a closer look at what Walmart will be offering for Black Friday 2016 when it comes to video games. Walmart Black Friday 2016 Console Bundles For Black Friday, Walmart will be selling the Battlefield 1 Xbox One S 500 GB Bundle for only $249, from the original price of $299. Gamers who prefer Sony over Microsoft will not be left in the dark though, as Walmart is also going to have a special price on the Uncharted 4 PlayStation 4 500 GB Slim Bundle. Originally for $299, the retailer will also be slashing the price of the bundle to only $249. For those who prefer handheld consoles, Walmart will also be participating in the $100 offer by Nintendo for the New Nintendo 3DS for special-edition systems that come with a black-and-white color scheme. The original price of the New Nintendo 3DS is $179. Walmart Black Friday 2016 Video Game Accessories For gamers who already own either the Xbox One or the PlayStation 4 and might need a replacement for their controllers due to all the button mashing, Walmart is offering gamepads for both consoles at only $39, down from the original price of $60 each. Walmart Black Friday 2016 Video Game Titles Walmart will be offering the Guitar Hero 2 Bundle for the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 for only $49, from the original price of $75. Gamers will also be able to buy the Skylanders Imaginators Starter Pack and the LEGO Dimensions Starter Pack, both for the PlayStation 4, for only $39. Customers will also be able to buy the recently released Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare and Modern Warfare Remastered bundle for only $57, from the original price of $80. Two more recently released games, Battlefield 1 and Titanfall 2, will be sold for only $27, compared with the current price of $60. There will be several titles that will be sold for only $35, including Overwatch, Destiny: The Collection, Gears of War 4 and Mafia III. There will also be other recent games that will be sold for only $27, including WWE 2K17, NBA 2K17, Madden NFL 17, FIFA 17. Ready For Black Friday 2016? Walmart will launch its Black Friday 2016 offers on its website starting 12:01 a.m. ET on Thanksgiving, Nov. 24, with physical stores to open at 6:00 p.m. local time on the same day. While waiting for the holiday shopping, feel free to browse through what other retailers such as Sears, Kohl's and Amazon have to offer. TAG Walmart, Playstation 4, PlayStation 4 Slim, PS4 Slim, Xbox One, Xbox One S © 2016 Tech Times, All rights reserved. Do not reproduce without permission. Talk Business & Politics you're viewing Statewide change region Central Arkansas Northeast Arkansas Northwest Arkansas Fort Smith area Save Statewide Name Menu Microsites Finance Energy Startup Manufacturing Tourism Healthcare Close Business Politics Video / Podcasts Advertise Contact Us Community Member stories Create an account Submit a blog post Close Wal-Mart welcomes veterans to its Bentonville headquarters in honor of Veterans Day by Kim Souza. Published Nov 11th, 2016 4:57 pm ksouza@talkbusiness.net / @tbarkansas Wal-Mart Stores CEO Doug McMillon on Friday asked Hoyt Williams, a 93-year-old World War II veteran who works as a greeter in Trion, Ga., if he had any advice for the audience. “Just hang in there,” Williams answered. At the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of November, Wal-Mart Stores rolled out the red carpet for several World War II veterans who work or whose families work within the retailer’s vast ranks. The event was held at the retailer’s Bentonville headquarters. Williams served in the European and South Pacific Campaigns of WW II. After Potsdam, he was not ready to leave the military and return to civilian life so he was shipped to Seattle and then re-deployed to the Philippines until the war ended. Gary Profit, senior director of Wal-Mart’s military programs, said serving in both campaigns is rare, but then again so is someone who at 93 still wants to get more hours on the job. Williams has been a Walmart U.S. employee for the 23 years, a job he told Talk Business & Politics he sought after retiring from a 40-year run in the grocery business in his home town. “I told my wife when we left the grocery business and I was tired of mowing the lawn that it was time for me go back to work. I went down to my local Walmart and the assistant manager knew me. Her family used to buy groceries from me when she was a little girl. She said they could put me to work even though I was 70 years old and they did,” Williams said. He’s grateful the job which he works 4 days a week, but said he’d like to get mores if the store manager would given them. “Pay day is the best thing about the job,” he said. “I also like being with the people, retail is what I know,” Williams said. Wal-Mart Stores CEO Doug McMillon and Lois Bouton, who served as a “SPAR” with the U.S. Coast Guard between 1943-1945. SPARs comes from the Latin and English translations of the Coast Guard’s motto, Semper Paratus! Always Ready! He said over the past 23 years he’s had several jobs at his local Walmart store working in various departments including sporting goods, hardware, electronics and even fabric before transitioning to greeter nearly 4 years ago. Wal-Mart has made clear its commitments to hire veterans of all ages. In 2013 Walmart U.S. committed to hiring 100,000 veterans in five years, but McMillon said the retailer accomplished that goal in three years. The company reassessed the goal in 2013 to hire 250,000 by 2020, setting the bar higher. Since 2013, McMillon said the retailer has hired 153,000 veterans and 19,000 of them have been promoted. McMillon introduced Johnny Martin, who works in asset management for the Sam’s Club in Oklahoma City. Martin is in the U.S. Army reserves and has served three tours in Iraq – totaling more than 32 months. He has a master’s degree and still had trouble finding work after returning home in 2014. He said Target passed on him, saying he was “too professional” essentially over-qualified for the positions they had open. Martin said he kept a running total of his jobs applications – 152 – before he landed a job at Sam’s Club. “I took an overnight position and thought I would work on finding career employment in the day. But I quickly saw it was working out and was promoted to a department level supervisory role in a short time frame. I was encouraged to apply for the asset management position at the new Sam’s Club but I thought it would go to some with lots more experience. I had only 14 months with Sam’s Club at the time,” Martin said. Martin was called to deploy just after Thanksgiving for a short tour in the Ukraine. “I have found Walmart’s commitment to veterans is not just an empty HR promise,” he said. Other speakers at the Veterans Day event included James McDonough Jr.. director of the Institute for Veteran and Military Families. Together with more than $40 million in funding from the Walmart Foundation, IVMF has programs in North Carolina, New York and most recently San Antonio, Texas. The programs work to help veterans today returning from service transition back into the workforce, school or some other form of service. He said someone retiring or coming home from extended service is jobless and sometimes homeless. While there are many programs and employers to help there is not anyone to help make the connections in what is a very fragmented sector. Helping veterans navigate the services and employment landscape is what IVMS does. Rear Admiral Terence McKnight (retired) also spoke at the event about the service today in the 21st Century. He remembers well the call he got while serving in the Pentagon in 2009 to help try and save merchant Captain Richard Phillips who was under attack by Somali pirates in the Gulf of Aden. During 2007-2011, was in charge of operations to chase modern-day pirates that were a threat to commerce. “We have the greatest Navy in the world but we were not trained to chase pirates. I was the most scared guy out there. The Somali pirates do it out of desperation and annual income of just $350. Half of those pirates who go to sea don’t return. They have nothing to lose,” he said. Keeping the passage clear through the Gulf of Aden is crucial to commerce as some 25,000 ships pass through there annually. At the time of the pirate crusades he said there was not enough Coast Guard and Navy ships policing the region. He said the first and second groups his team captured, were released because the U.S. did not have a plan in place on how to handle those captured. He said those who had the misfortune to be captured by the Russians were not as fortunate. Walmart officials also encouraged the several hundred in attendance to support the “Green Light A Vet” marketing program the retailer introduced this time last year.  Profit said the idea of replacing an outdoor light bulb with a green bulb is hit, so much so that the retailer ran out of green light bulbs last year. Walmart said it sold 2 million green lights last year, and Profit said supplies are good because they have a better estimate on demand. Contests Deals Service Directory Print Display Ads Nifty Nickel FAQ   You are here Home » Business Nationwide discount chain...On its 25th anniversary,...     Posted November 11, 2016 - 2:39pmUpdated November 11, 2016 - 3:45pm Walmart, Target plan sales blitzes for evening of Thanksgiving Day Walmart, Target plan sales blitzes for evening of Thanksgiving Day A customer guides her shopping carts with televisions purchased at a Target Store in Colma, Calif., in 2011. (Jeff Chiu/AP) By SARAH HALZACK WASHINGTON POST Walmart and Target each plan to kick off their in-store Black Friday sales at 6 p.m. on Thanksgiving, repeating their start-times from last year and throwing some cold water on the notion that Turkey Day deals blitzes may be falling out of style. Earlier in the season, the Mall of America announced it would be shuttering its doors on the holiday after being open in previous years. Office Depot, too, made a similar reversal of course. But the plans from the big-box behemoths — as well as from Macy’s, Kohl’s and Toys R Us — suggest the Thanksgiving Day shopping tradition is going strong. Walmart said it will be “dramatically increasing” the amount of inventory it has available for online deal hunters, offering some 50 percent more Black Friday merchandise this year on the Web than last year. “We really pride ourselves on not being the retailer who advertises a great price but then only has a few available for the customers,” said Steve Bratspies, the chief merchandising officer at Walmart U.S., during a conference call with reporters. Walmart said its offerings this year would include items such as a Samsung 50-inch 4K television for $398 and movies that cost $1.99. Target, meanwhile, was touting deals such as an iPad Air 2 for $274 and 30 percent off apparel. Oh, and remember that giant $10 teddy bear that was all over social media last Black Friday? The retailer is bringing it back, and has bought 20 percent more inventory this time around. Both chains will start their online Black Friday sales in the early morning hours on Thanksgiving. And both will be offering a steady trickle of discounts over the next two weeks to encourage customers to get in the holiday spirit. In earlier announcements about their seasonal plans, Target and Walmart stressed they were trying to focus on making their promotions simple this time around. In the past, it seems, shoppers have been confused by a cavalcade of coupons or staggered sale starting times. At Target, that means returning to the “10 days of deals” program, something the retailer tried last year in which it touted a single big promotion each day starting the weekend before Thanksgiving. Walmart is also aiming for simple: Besides its limited-time Black Friday discounts, it plans to keep the rest of its price cuts in place for the duration of the November and December rush. The National Retail Federation, an industry trade group, forecasts that stores will ring up a healthy 3.6 percent increase in sales this holiday season. That would be an improvement from last year, when sales growth was up just 3 percent. We should soon get a clearer idea of what kind of momentum big retail has headed into this all-important time of year: Macy’s is set to report earnings Thursday morning, and Walmart, Target, Best Buy and others will do so in the following week.
